rules: Rule1: Provided that Congress allocates budget for habitat restoration, agencies implement the habitat restoration program.
Rule2: If environmental groups support the habitat program, then it follows that if agencies implement the habitat restoration program, society achieves conservation goals.
Rule3: In case industry groups oppose the habitat program, then when agencies implement the habitat restoration program, society achieves conservation goals.

Rule4: Provided that environmental groups file a lawsuit against agencies, then if agencies accelerate implementation of the habitat program, agencies do not delay implementation of the habitat program.
Rule5: Environmental groups file a lawsuit against agencies or environmental groups negotiate a settlement with agencies.

Rule6: Whenever environmental groups negotiate a settlement with agencies, then if agencies accelerate implementation of the habitat program, agencies do not delay implementation of the habitat program.
Rule7: Under the condition that Congress passes a bill on conservation funding, then if Congress increases funding for conservation, it is not the case that Congress reduces funding for conservation.
Rule8: If Congress overrides the president's veto, then the conservation bill becomes law.
Rule9: Provided that agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems, society achieves conservation goals.
Rule10: If agencies monitor species classified as endangered, then either agencies designate wildlife corridors for ecosystems or agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems.
Rule11: In case agencies track populations of endangered species, then agencies designate wildlife corridors for ecosystems or agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems.
Rule12: If scientists recommend action to Congress, then agencies report findings to Congress.
Rule13: Provided that Congress rejects legislation concerning pesticide ban, then it is not the case that Congress approves legislation concerning pesticide ban.
Rule14: If scientists provide data to agencies, then agencies monitor species classified as endangered or agencies track populations of endangered species.
Rule15: Under the condition that agencies issue guidance on pesticides, agencies update regulations on pesticides.
Rule16: Provided that agencies review the impact of development projects, agencies assess risks of development projects.
Rule17: In case agencies assess risks of development projects, agencies require modifications to development projects.

Rule18: If agencies approve development projects, then it follows that if agencies require modifications to development projects, then when agencies enforce the deadline for compliance, agencies do not extend the deadline for compliance.
Rule19: Provided that agencies grant permits to developers, agencies approve development projects.
Rule20: Agencies grant permits to developers or agencies deny permits to developers.
Rule21: Under the condition that agencies deny permits to developers, agencies approve development projects.
Rule22: Provided that agencies investigate complaints from the public, agencies hold hearings with the public.
Rule23: Agencies investigate complaints from the public or agencies respond to inquiries from the public.

Rule24: Whenever agencies respond to inquiries from the public, then if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals, then Congress does not approve legislation concerning pesticide ban.

Rule25: In case agencies issue rulings to the public, then if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals, then Congress does not approve legislation concerning pesticide ban.
Rule26: Whenever agencies coordinate efforts with states, then if agencies uphold complaints from the public, agencies do not dismiss complaints from the public.
Rule27: Provided that agencies develop guidelines for states, agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems.
Rule28: Agencies develop guidelines for states or agencies share data with states.
Rule29: If scientists analyze data for agencies, scientists publish reports for agencies.
Rule30: Scientists analyze data for agencies or scientists conduct field studies for agencies.
Rule31: Under the condition that scientists conduct field studies for agencies, scientists provide data to agencies.
Rule32: In case scientists publish reports for agencies, scientists recommend action to Congress.
Rule33: Scientists publish a study on pesticide effects or it is not the case that scientists conduct research on pesticide effects.
Rule34: If scientists testify at congressional hearings, then scientists do not publish a study on pesticide effects.
Rule35: Provided that scientists are invited to congressional hearings, scientists testify at congressional hearings.
Rule36: Whenever Congress funds research on native plants, society achieves conservation goals.
Rule37: Congress funds research on native plants or Congress allocates budget for habitat restoration.
Rule38: If it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals, then Congress approves legislation concerning pesticide ban.
Rule39: If it is not the case that environmental groups support the habitat program or industry groups oppose the habitat program, then agencies delay implementation of the habitat program.
Rule40: In case it is not the case that environmental groups support the habitat program or industry groups oppose the habitat program, agencies accelerate implementation of the habitat program.
Rule41: Provided that it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies, agencies issue guidance on pesticides.
Rule42: Under the condition that it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies, agencies do not update regulations on pesticides.
Rule43: If it is not the case that if agencies hold hearings with the public then agencies issue rulings to the public, agencies dismiss complaints from the public.
Rule44: In case it is not the case that if agencies hold hearings with the public then agencies issue rulings to the public, agencies uphold complaints from the public.

Rule45: Provided that it is not the case that if agencies share data with states then agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems, there is a conflict of jurisdiction between agencies and states.

Rule46: Under the condition that it is not the case that if agencies resolve disputes with states then if it is not the case that if agencies share data with states then agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems then there is no conflict of jurisdiction between agencies and states, agencies escalate disputes with states.

Rule47: In case it is not the case that if agencies resolve disputes with states then if it is not the case that if agencies share data with states then agencies establish protected areas for ecosystems then there is no conflict of jurisdiction between agencies and states, agencies do not escalate disputes with states.

Rule48: Provided that it is not the case that if agencies mediate negotiations among stakeholders then if it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies then agencies update regulations on pesticides, agencies fail in mediation with stakeholders.

Rule49: If it is not the case that if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals then Congress rejects legislation concerning pesticide ban, agencies extend the deadline for compliance.

Rule50: Under the condition that it is not the case that if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals then Congress rejects legislation concerning pesticide ban, agencies enforce the deadline for compliance.

Rule51: In case it is not the case that if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals then Congress rejects legislation concerning pesticide ban, Congress amends legislation concerning pesticide ban.

Rule52: Whenever it is not the case that if it is not the case that if Congress supports biodiversity protection then society achieves conservation goals then Congress rejects legislation concerning pesticide ban, Congress does not amend legislation concerning pesticide ban.

Rule53: If it is not the case that if it is not the case that if agencies mediate negotiations among stakeholders then if it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies then agencies update regulations on pesticides then agencies do not fail in mediation with stakeholders, stakeholders initiate litigation against agencies.

Rule54: Provided that it is not the case that if it is not the case that if it is not the case that if agencies mediate negotiations among stakeholders then if it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies then agencies update regulations on pesticides then agencies do not fail in mediation with stakeholders then stakeholders do not initiate litigation against agencies, stakeholders reach an agreement with agencies.

Rule55: In case it is not the case that if it is not the case that if it is not the case that if agencies mediate negotiations among stakeholders then if it is not the case that scientists recommend action to Congress or scientists provide data to agencies then agencies update regulations on pesticides then agencies do not fail in mediation with stakeholders then stakeholders do not initiate litigation against agencies, stakeholders do not reach an agreement with agencies.

Rule56: If it is not the case that if it is not the case that Congress passes a bill on conservation funding then the president vetoes the bill on conservation funding, Congress overrides the president's veto.
Rule57: Under the condition that society does not achieve conservation goals, Congress reduces funding for conservation.
Rule58: In case society does not achieve conservation goals, scientists conduct research on pesticide effects.
facts: Fact2: Congress increases funding for conservation.
Fact3: Agencies review the impact of development projects.
Fact4: Agencies coordinate efforts with states.
Fact5: Agencies resolve disputes with states.
Fact6: Agencies mediate negotiations among stakeholders.
Fact7: Scientists are invited to congressional hearings.
Fact8: It is not the case that the president vetoes the bill on conservation funding.
Fact9: It is not the case that the conservation bill becomes law.
Fact10: It is not the case that agencies designate wildlife corridors for ecosystems.
Fact11: It is not the case that agencies report findings to Congress.
